author: @user-re1gc9sq6g
text:
My 5M pro messed up device binding on the 1st day 2nd test. It ran into an error, corrupted, factory reset, can't bind again, serial number if abcdefg. So I gave up flashforge orca slicer. Used original orca slicer. It was very easy. Just pick the model from devices, set the correct IP (I used both WiFi and LAN, both worked perfectly). I'm thinking of installing Klipper CFW to minimize waste. After all done, I tried their flexible PLA, it made the extruder stuck (my mistake when switching from petg to pla I've selected PLA as the new filament which wasn't hot enough to remove old PETG), I had to completely disassemble the whole extruder unit to fix this (it went deep in). This was my very first time ever learning about 3D printing and starting it. But I've managed to get everything done by myself without ever needing anyone's help and learned everything in hard way. I specifically choose 5M pro above any other printer is because the built in HEPA filter which is very important to as I'm concerned about health effects. I haven't found this feature in any other printer (I have no problem affording high end printers but non of them had feature). I know I should've been pissed at flashforge for giving me such a hard time but it was very well built and if you're resourceful, you can tackle all those things and get behind this well made printer. The software is messed up but as a software engineer, I didn't had any problem with switching from vendor locking sw. As a person who never even watched a single video of 3D printing before trying it by myself, I can assure this printer is very beginner friendly. 
It's been a week now and I made so many flawless prints with different materials and switching materials in between prints, switching different nozzles, etc and not a single print failed even when I brought cheap petg for testing.

The Flashforge AD5* backplates are shockingly poor in terms of PSU, SBC, and cooling quality. There are even long threads on how to make sure the cables are connected properly, because they can come undone from the pure shaking of the printer. You'd think they would have tested that!

author: @anthonylong5870
text: This is the only multicolor printer that allows you to use TPU .  The version 1 did it without any issues, It actually can even mix TPU and other filaments in 1 print.  Thats actually ground breaking.  Btw your dellusional saying Bambus AMS can use "all spools well".  That is COMPLETELY FALSE.  So much so people have to use makeshift adapters on several brands not named Bambu

author: @donnyriggz
text:
You absolutely cannot run TPU through this printer and expect it to work every time. I've tried it and I've had more failed than successful prints. It "can" work, but you're likely going to need several attempts and may have to clear an extruder jam a couple times. Not worth the headache. 

The spool holders this printer shipped with the early release models absolutely cannot use all spools well. Cardboard spools sit at a weird angle and the edges of the spool rub against the holder, if it's one of the top spools it drops ground bits of cardboard onto the spools below it. This also causes a lot of resistance which the IFS doesn't handle well at all throwing out frequent errors because it can't feed the filament. Also most mini-spools also do not fit. You would also need different spool adapters for this printer as well and the new spool holders are basically copying the A1 style and will also likely not fit all spools.

author: @brianrowland9993
text:
An excellent comprehensive review that does a great job of describing pros and cons of the H2D which ticks most boxes.
One of the best I have seen and as a prospective buyer provides some confidence in the purchase of the machine.
One area that needs more explanation is the need for  a sacrificial tower using multi  filament colours to avoid carryover.
This also wastes a LOT of filament (!)   Why can't this be solved by extending hot end changeover time?
Does this requirement only apply to printing more than two colours?
I haven't seen the sacrificial tower requirement mentioned in H2S reviews - presumably this version also needs a sacrificial tower as well?
Did you find the print quality improved over say the X1C?

author: @RickyImpey
text: The simple explanation that I have seen is that the nozzle pressure needs to be primed before it starts printing again. Therefore the prime tower is always needed for any filament or nozzle changes to avoid spots of under or over extrusion on your print as the filament begins to extrude.

author: @psergiu
text: On a US 15A circuit, that 15 Amp value is the absolute maximum allowed short peak current draw. Any sustained current draw has to be a maximum of 80% of the abs max - in this case 12A. So the max sustained power draw for a 15A circuit is then 120v x 12A = 1440W. Thus, basically, the H2D must be the only device on that 15A circuit.

author: @lotsad1234
text: Thats a issue only during the initial 30 seconds when is doing the initial bed heating after that the power draw should be similar to any other printer

author: @CL-gq3no
text: @lotsad1234, It's not even an issue during bed heating.  It is the active chamber heater that uses ~1000 watts, but as you said that is only initially.  After that, it cycles on and off and only for filaments that need it.  I found this out while trying to run it from a UPS.  Only used a few hundred watts for low temp filaments during initial heating, but for ABS it overloaded the UPS while heating the chamber.

author: @dan-nutu
text: If you want convenience and saving your time, then these are good options. If on the other hand you want to save money, you can use 4 liter airtight cereal boxes and adapt them into filament dry boxes by printing the required parts. There is a guy on YT who has a whole system, you can stack them, use them on the dryer etc. Very nice, but it takes time to print and assemble all those. But in the end each box adds up to only around ‚Ç¨10, which can make a significant difference if you need lots of boxes to store your filament ready to print. Hope this helps someone! :)

author: @logicalfundy
text:
I'm sorry - no. Too expensive. I'm tired of expensive dryers, and while I'd be willing to pay a bit more for a 2 in 1, the price of the boxes needs to go down. I've got a lot of filament, and I'd need to spend probably thousands of dollars on the boxes alone to store all of them. I tried PolyDryer, but I struggle to buy enough boxes to hold all of my filament. To me, that's not reasonably priced.

Also, a question: Has anybody actually had problems with their filament because of a hot spot in a dryer? Filament is usually in the dryer for multiple hours, so it should all get dry as the air circulates and the moisture is vented.

author: @GMx_1
text:
Great review of this product.  Dryers have certainly improved quite a lot over the past year or 2. I am the type to do a bit of over analysis and it is not easy to compare these different brands of dryers to each other as it is not entirely clear what type of setup works the best, both ease of use but also the performance of the device itself.  

It would be nice if there was a standardized way to test one of these, things like quantified weight before and weight after drying or graph of temp and humidity over time or a weight and tensile test on a 3 inch long sample before and after drying. With samples taken from the top, bottom, outside and inside of the spool.  Standardizing the testing would be key to truly comparing and evaluating these devices.

Again great video, i think you noted some very interesting and inciteful points and i really appreciate channels like yours, they are very important to this hobby and industry.  Cheers

author: @runesblog
text: 10:26 Will the AMS HT be able to feed and retract the fiber reinforced materials? In other words: Will a combination of the AMS and the AMS HT allow me to switch between PLA and PA6-CF in Bambu Studio without having to manually insert or retract the filament? So it will be just like switching between different filaments in the same AMS?

author: @RickyImpey
text: Yes, you can do it but Bambu Lab advise to not feed fiber filaments through their AMS units. I think this is because of the wear it will cause, even though the have switched to ceramic filament inlets now.

author: @runesblog
text: @ Thanks. This is very disappointing. Just found on the official website that only reinforced PLA, PAHT and PETG are supported. PA6-CF, PPA-CF, and PPS-CF are not supported.

author: @rileyneufeld7001
text: This is a big disappointment. The AMS2 should've been redesigned to allow fiber reinforced filaments. Or easily replaceable inlets that when the fibers do wear thru the inlets they can be replaced for cheap. Why else have the heated chamber and all these automated processes if you can't use the top tier engineering grade filaments without manually loading them.

author: @runesblog
text: @ Exactly.

author: @Todestelzer
text:
@runesblog PPA-CF is too brittle. I printed it a couple times and it snaps like bad PLA. No way it will work in the AMS.

author: @GregWheat-yb6br
text: I'm here today because half through a PLA print, my hot end can suddenly not keep up with the 215 degree temp being demanded.  It's falling down to 206 degrees on fast sections.  This caused an error and after a restart and much experimenting, it's not going away with software fixes.  So I've emailed them as it's been less than a year.  I'm not sure if it's the hot end or the supply to the hot end but we'll see how they respond.  My other complaint with this machine all along is that the bed seems to warp when heated or is just inconsistent, even with what I consider thorough leveling and setup in the mesh side of things.  Large prints I have issues with and I can't for the life of me get this thing to print multiple things at once without a very high risk of failure on the first layers.  This being the case, I print by object not by layer but that does have a lot of limitations.  What a bummer.  Otherwise a quite decent machine.

author: @cueball981
text:
Just checking the boxes...

Did you try performing the manual bed level then recalibrate the bed mesh? Also, I found that it really helps to perform a new bed mesh anytime I switch to a different filament that requires a different bed temperature.

Doing these things, I'm getting a perfect first layer no matter where I print on the bed.

author: @bennetb01
text:
I bought one of these and it's been the most unreliable printer I have EVER owned.

Bed leveling issues showed that the piezo sensors were broken.  2 weren't even plugged in.    Still not confident in high temp bed leveling.

WIFI has tons of packet loss  I had to use a wired external wireless bridge to get it reliably working.   It's not my wifi it's the printer

The fan on the chamber heater failed after only a low number of hours of use (canceling the print mid job no less).

The mainboard gets SUPER toasty and the little fan is inadiquate.

My mainboard failed.  This was my fault but plugging in a 0.8a chamber fan into it, but there was zero overcurrent protection and the transitor just let out the magic smoke.

The touchscreen interface is awful.

Don't buy this printer ever.

author: @FromDesertTown
text:
I have a first batch "v1" Plus 4 too. I had a lot of issues as well, but it works fine every time now. To anyone who buys a "v1" Plus 4, I recommend modding several things right away to save future headaches:
- Install a Beacon Rev.H before your piezo sensor burns out. You'll be happy with it - it massively speeds up bed leveling and is very precise and accurate.
- Install an Omron SSR if you live in a 110v country before your OEM SSR melts (look up "Omron SSR Plus 4").
- Print and install an improved enclosure for the chamber heater which prevents heat creep.
- Remove PEI wipe from the nozzle wipe routine (to prevent future nozzle damage). The Plus 4 community made an improved wiping routine that works well with only the silicone pad.

author: @alexboyceboyceaerospacehobbies
text:
I'll never give Qidi another chance as I've had poor experiences two different times with their products. I've  had a 3D print farm for the last 8 years and have tried many different printers over the years. About 6 years ago I bought two Qidi fully enclosed printers based on rave reviews on YouTube. I tried them out for a month and could never get the printers to print ABS with any decent surface quality plus they both had multiple mid print software issues. Luckily I had bought them on Amazon so returning them was not an issue. During the month I had contacted Qidi multiple times about both the print quality and the software glitches and went around and around with them. They expect you to wait for parts that they want to send you to fix their guess at what the problems are and also to basically rebuild brand new printers.

Then, last year (2024) I foolishly gave them another chance based on the multiple great reviews on their Qidi X-Max3 large format printer. I foolishly made the mistake of buying the printer directly from the Qidi website. I received the printer in good shape and got a couple of good ABS prints before the error messages started occurring mid print. I contacted Qidi and they sent me a ton of replacement parts to fix my NEW PRINTER. I had to install a replacement BL Touch (actually a cheap Chinese clone), communication and power cables from the mother board to the print head, replacement printhead cover with additional cooling fan, chamber heater fan and heat element, etc. Then install/flash new firmware. Guess what, after about 4 hours later and a ton of work the printer still had the error messages as soon as the print chamber warmed up! I contacted them again and told them that I wanted to return the printer for a full refund and their VERY INSISTANT response was we'll send you more parts (inductive probe to replace the BL touch for bed leveling). At this point I didn't want to waste any more time on their defective product plus Changing to an inductive probe meant installing a magnetic sheet over the printers nice magnetic bed and losing build height. No matter what I said they would not agree to take their printer back and give me a refund. I finally had to file for a chargeback with my credit card company to get my $1000 back ( I had to send them the entire email chain showing that I had asked Qidi over 15 times for a refund and a shipping label to return the printer). Now I have a large paper weight next to my print farm on its own table as a reminder to NEVER EVER EVER buy from Qidi again...

author: @etwkoelle6487
text:
Sorry to say that, but watching this video published four to five months after the Plus4 entering the market is kind of painful. 

For me as a Plus4 owner it's very obvious that you, Ricky, did not really spent much time with the Plus4. There are so many well know flaws besides the SSR gate, which are not mentioned here. And also in case of the malfunctioning 110V SSR, QIDI's solution is not fully satisfying: Due to the issues QIDI rolled out a new firmware for all variants (110V and 220V), just lowering the power for the chamber heater. So, while fixing the 110V issues, the actual Plus4's don't have the originallay advertised 400W chamber heater any more, as the power is limited (to a power factor of 40%) by FW update.

Further, you mention the active carbon filter, which is by design not suitable for filtering. It's advertised by QIDI as a "chamber circulation (!)" with active carbon filtration. If it would have been implemented as "circulation" it would make sense. In fact it's just an exhaust fan, directly blowing the warm air out of the housing into the room, with minimal contact time for the air to be filtered. There are mods already available, to make it circulating, but the stock implementation does not make sense at all.

Besides that the auxiliary fan is BS by design. On the one hand side it's not recommended for larger models due to the one sided air flow. More critical is, that it counteracts to the cooling fan from cold end of the print head, leading to clogging for certain materials like PETG. Then there are massive issues with bed leveling and nozzles scratching through the build plate, due to either defective piezo sensors or due to a very special modification by QIDI of the klipper based firmware.

Don't get me wrong: after spending much time with the Plus4 and optimizing things, the Plus4 is a great printer. But the "review" of this video is nothing more than going through the official specification.

author: @kylewellman402
text:
Yeah i absolutely love the plus 4. Using it for functional prints for my hobby machine shop, plus it gives me high end filament capabilities which just increases the options i have for customers. I've had all sorts of requests for custom side panels or fenders for dirt bikes and the little Honda Groms. Its just the perfect machine thats still affordable for hobby shops like me. Dont have a huge budget so affordability is awesome. Especially since the quality and ability is damn near industrial level. I have no complaints. Well, one, but its minor.

If you get a filament clog or run out of filament mid print, the language used for some of the options can be confusing. The proper way to continue involves going to the control screen and hitting the play button. But if you mistakingly hit "load filament" like youd think you would need to after you ran out, it will go through the homing sequence and start to probe the bed, which is no bueno if you have a print sitting in the middle of the bed. Luckily, even in a "oh shit" moment i was able to open the door and pull the PEI sheet off the bed as the nozzle was slow motion coming to destroy the print lol. This caused the nozzle to poke a small hole in the magnetic sheet though before it finally bottomed out on the aluminum bed. No real damage done, but a big lesson learned.

author: @gunsmoke132
text:
Actually yeah, I don't remember exactly what I did or what fixed it but I had to do a couple things in order to get it to work but now that it's working I'd say it's 90% flawless it still has a hiccup here and there but so far I'm relatively satisfied. I did a couple things at once so I'm not too sure what made a difference but if you get one and or some else is having issues:

I loosened the bed tramming knobs and leveled it with cheps ez 3d light lvl sensor 
Replaced the bed sensors and aux boards
Changed some code in the config file as per supports suggestion (I don't think it did anything tbh)
And I reflashed the firmware via USB and reset to factory defaults 

After this it was no longer digging the nozzle into the bed on a cold print but was being finicky with prints if it was already warm which is an issue for engineering prints but theirs a mod online that makes it so the chamber temp sensor is more accurate it's literally a copy and paste ordeal and I've been printing PC like it's pla‚Äã

So in all, yeah it's killing it right now but there's a chance you might need to do an hour or so of tweaking out of the box to get it to where it needs to be. Obviously it took me more than an hour because I had to figure all this out on my own but let my pain and suffering not go in vein lol@matthewtaylor2344

text: I have a Qidi Q1 Pro that worked great for 10 months. However, it has recently started jamming the print head into the right rear corner of the print bed and will not print anything. I have been emailing their support team back and forth for months, since December, but the service has been atrocious. They keep saying they will help resolve the issue, but after over 20 emails and months of waiting, the printer is still not working. It was a fantastic machine until it broke down. Unfortunately, I have received no assistance in getting it working again, even though it is still under warranty. I would not recommend this printer to anyone, as it seems that once it fails, you are left without any support.

author: @colinward1581
text: How Qidi Finally Fixed It! LOL, they didn't. There are still tons of issues with it beyond the SSR & lousy job of wiring. Don't get me wrong, for the price and with it's features and build volume it was and is a bargain. But the new ceramic heatbrake is prone to breaking when the nozzle gets hung on the PEI wiper, the chamber heater has reduced output which means it takes a very long time to heat up the chamber for filaments like ASA for example, the location of the chamber temperature sensor causes inaccurate readings that can lead to some dangerous temperatures in the chamber, the hotend fan duct is offset resulting in poor cooling, the peizo sensors are failing frequently due to heat, and there are problems with the inductive bed probes due to heat as well. So if you plan to consistently print filaments that require high bed temperatures you may need a lot of mods/upgrades to get stable performance from the Plus 4. While you may not have encountered some of these issues, there is a Discord Plus 4 group, a Plus 4 Github group, and multiple FB groups with ample info on these issues and more. Personally I am having z offset inconsitency and I'm having the retram the bed daily or my 1st layer gets way too squished, and it takes forever to heat up the chamber. Other than that I am quite happy with my plus 4. I am planning to mod the chamber heater enclosure, do the Dynamic Chamber Temperature Manager mod, and change the behavior of the bed mesh macro, as well as printing a better hotend fan duct. If the chamber heating mods and the bed mesh macro tweaks don't solve my Z offset consinency I will probably do the Beacon inductive probe mod. I have already done the mainboard fan upgrade, and the HEPA filter mod for the exhaust fan. Great video, keep 'm coming!

author: @iseolake
text: Nice review. This is probably the best printer for my use case, if it can actually print objects that are 300mmx300mm on the bed?  The claim is 305x305. The reason I ask is that I recently learned that a Bambu with an advertised 256 cubed build volume can actually only print to 238 x 228 x 250 mm.  Apparently the filament cutter placement and some limitation in z hop make the entire volume unusable without modifying the printer. I would hate to discover a limitation like this after purchasing a printer.

author: @802Garage
text: There are very small exclusion zones at the rear left and front right of the bed. The maximum perfect square you can print is around 295X295, I believe. You can still print a 305 diameter circle for example or anything 305 wide and tall that isn't perfectly square. There is also a mod to reduce the front right exclusion zone size. I've never really seen it actually stop someone from printing something.

author: @Ebonyqwe
text:
I found this on the qidi website about this printer.     

 ‚ÄúIt is recommended to use only one type of filament in a single nozzle. Switching between multiple filaments in one nozzle may cause nozzle blockage.‚Äù       

Looking at the price of the nozzles is going to be a pretty expensive process and basically excludes a multi filament AMS style system

author: @Kimberlie1
text: You can change the filament, but you need to make sure that the previous filament has been cleaned. If you print with high-temperature filament and then immediately change to PLA with a lower printing temperature, it is likely to be clogged due to incomplete cleaning.

author: @coledavidson5630
text: Nobody is going to swap nozzles for every material, and also you aren't supposed to use different materials in one print with an AMS style system anyway. It can cause clogs/jams and layer separation

author: @802Garage
text: Love my Plus4 I got at launch. I use Orca Slicer as well. I have had very few issues. I replaced the chamber heater board without a problem. I also had the stainless steel heat break nozzle, but only had a few clogs on picky filaments. The ceramic heat break nozzle completely fixed it. It's true the Plus4 can produce nearly completely VFA prints at great speeds. There is no other printer this capable which can print this large at anywhere close to as low a price. It's essentially an X1E competitor, but larger, for way less money. There were teething issues and I don't think it's the right printer for someone who absolutely can't tinker, but it's great for advanced users and high end filaments. Qidi customer support is also still excellent.

author: @802Garage

I have seen a variety of issues, but I can't say how common they are. Overall most people seem happy with their K2 Plus, but I worry mostly about VFA and potentially bed stability. They seem to use cheap Z nuts and may have poor layer stacking as a result. Could only be a few specific printers though. I'd watch a lot of reviews. For my money, the Plus4 would be plenty, especially since I don't care about multi-color. Once the Qidi Box is released it will have that option as well. If you really want the larger size, I'd say that makes the K2 Plus your option.

author: @TheGamersRace
text: The K2 seems to have a ton of struggles right now, where this printer seems to be over them as far as I can tell.

author: @coledavidson5630
text: ‚Äã@TheGamersRace I think they both still have plenty of issues. This printer has problems with nozzles breaking repeatedly, the heater and heater fan have way higher failure rates than is reasonable, and the bed leveling piezos fail on many units causing the nozzle to dig into the bed. There's also the alleged house fire, but we'll have to wait and see how legit that is. Just for my own information, what are the common issues with the K2? I haven't done as much research into it as I have for the Plus 4

author: @TheGamersRace
text:
@coledavidson5630¬† The ceramic heat breaks do break, but since those are technically wear items I can let that slide as they can be easily replaced.  The bed leveling piezos I haven't heard any issues with, but there was a out of box gcode offset issue they had when the printer was new that caused the issue you're describing.  That has been corrected.  The house fire was most likely an old chamber heater left installed, which while not an excuse for a housefire, this has been corrected on new models.  Agreeably we need more info on that particular case.  

As far as I know the K2 basically can't make it out the box without problems.  Firmware issue sprinkled with endless hardware issues.  I think the quality is just so poor that people genuinely can't get past 300hrs on it before having to RMA it.  I don't know of anyone in particular that hasn't had inexcusable problems, but I could be wrong.

author: @coledavidson5630
text: @TheGamersRace just bc it's a wear item doesn't mean it should break so frequently. Some people have had them break like once a week. It's an expensive part and shouldn't need to be replaced constantly under normal use conditions. The issue needs to be addressed. Also, the Reddit user with the house fire stated they had the new SSR installed and weren't even using the chamber heater when the fire occurred. But I agree that we'll have to wait and see how much truth there is to any of those claims. However, the gcode offset thing did not fully resolve the offset issues, MANY people still have the piezos fail to perform auto z offset correctly at high temperatures, causing the nozzle to gouge and scrape the bed

author: @TheGamersRace
text:
@coledavidson5630¬† The issue has been addressed, they released a new nozzle. The old one broke frequently sure, but the new one certainly hasn't.  They also replace any broken nozzles.  And what I meant by a wear item, is that they can still fix the problem and ship them out.  It's not a core component that cannot be replaced, nor is it a component that you shouldn't expect to have to replace.  There's also plenty of third party ones if the stock ones just aren't cutting it for you.  And let's not forget Bambu "the best printer manufacturer to date" can't even ship working replacement nozzles at all with a 80% failure rate... So much so people recommend just getting the 3rd party ones as they're more reliable... So it's not like they're the only company that have had issues, but their issues HAVE been addressed even if not completely solved for some.  

The actual piezo itself I have not heard really any problems with, it's all been about the offsets in the gcode and the bed temp problem.  I personally haven't had any problems with bedscraping, but I do plan to get some PPS-CF filament to try and will want to confirm this.  Also, as far as I'm aware, if you're not using Qidislicer you shouldn't have had the gcode issue in the first place.  Not an excuse, just an observation that if anyone is seriously considering this printer, most people will try to get them to use Orca and not QidiSlicer.

author: @802Garage
text: It is indeed open source. It's not the best Klipper implementation possible as it's based on a slightly older version and is not clean, but you can mess with it all you want. There is a great modding community for the printer already in terms of both software and hardware.

author: @802Garage
text: @NewSDCaller I wrote my reply without seeing your last one. Dirty doesn't mean not open source. It means some of the components of the Klipper install are modified so it is not a completely mainline version. Basically, clean Klipper is what you pull directly from the source and dirty is edited. You can have dirty closed or open source, but Qidi's is open.

author: @TC-hl1ws
text: Great video.  How is Qidi's parts inventory for replacement parts?

author: @802Garage
text: In terms of general parts like printhead, extruder, boards, fans, nozzles, it's all there and pretty affordable. The nozzles are a bit pricey, but the stock item is bi-metal and abrasive resistant. You shouldn't need to replace them often. If you need specific mechanical parts like say a frame piece, they are generally available from Qidi, but you have to go through customer service. Obviously you shouldn't need anything like that on a new printer, only if you dropped it or something. Lubing all the rods is definitely recommended to keep the bearings happy.

author: @SebasTian-od7oz
text:
You should not have disposed of the "faulty" cable. 
You could have stripped it to confirm the following suspicion and maybe show us an educational video as a result: 
‚ö†There is a chance that this was one of the increasing numbers of cases where the manufacturer did not embed the ground (protective earth - PE) wire to save money. ‚ö†
If I were you I'd check all my IEC connector cables for a missing ground connection, especially on devices in the style of laptop power supply bricks and anything with a plastic shell. 
Since devices with a non-conductive casing theoretically do not need a ground connection to be safe against giving you a shock when you touch the casing, manufacturers would get away with silently removing the ground wire in cables provided with such devices. 
What they do not take into consideration (or do not care about) is that somebody could swap their incomplete cable onto a metal encased device, which could be what happened in your case.

Also like others already noted: Even with the ground wire removed, the case should not be live. 
I'm a bit surprised that your appliance leakage current interrupter (ALCI or RCCB) does not trigger with the ground connection re-established. 
The voltage potential on the casing should create a current leakage in the PE wire and trigger your leakage current breaker (if the current would reach life-endangering levels). Maybe yours is faulty?
It wouldn't hurt to go to the switch box in your home and press the "manual trigger" test-button on your leakage current breaker (which you should do once every 6 months anyway). 
Just don't forget to switch off your PC and tell everybody in the household before, since this kills the power ;)

author: @Kimberlie1
text:
The SSR problem has been completely solved. 

I have Plus4 and Q1 Pro, so I didn't buy Elegoo CC. 

Although the price is very cheap, there is no innovation. I would rather spend a little more money to buy a machine with better performance. 

If you use this machine as the first printer to enter 3d printing, you can buy it. But in terms of subsequent development potential, Q1 Pro and Plus4 can meet the needs of more high-performance filaments. 

QIDI has always focused on the manufacture of fdm printers, but CC is Elegoo's first enclosed printer, so I still wait and see.

author: @ClagwellHoyt2095
text:
Capacitance between the heater wires and the metal bed will allow a leakage current to flow when the bed heaters is energized.  Normally that current is shunted to ground via the powerline safety grounding lead.  If that path is interrupted that will allow the full line voltage to appear on ay parts of the printer that are electrically connected to the bed.  
==> This can happen with any printer that uses line voltage on the bed heater. <==

correction: about half the line voltage will appear on the bed and connected parts.

author: @Vimes.
text:
Thanks for the "first thoughts" type video, appreciated.

I am not sure that you should have received a shock from the case, even with the noted issues on the socket and lead used. Surely the case still should not have done this.

I am yet to choose my very first 3d printer and your observations about the lack of a chamber heater also had concerned me when I had seen screenshots of this one online. Whilst I appreciate there is a cost factor, a chamber heater would only seem to compliment the potential that this would otherwise have.

I am pleased that you noted the filtration, being aware of the ideal being both HEPA certified and active carbon. Even printing PLA is not free from micro plastics concerns and whilst filtration can help, it has to be of the appropriate type to be meaningful.

Points taken regarding the choice of a closed type of firmware. I have begun to appreciate, having joined several discord channels for various 3d printer manufacturers etc, what it can mean to have a Klipper based firmware and Fluidd. Even though that might not seem so relevant for me at this point it is still a big put off for me to consider this one.

This next bit is only based on what I have picked up so far......

If I want to have the 3d printer lottery Gods on my side, first time buyer, and enjoy the best OOB experience with minimal fuss, then a Bambu type seems to be  a good choice.
At this point I would have no real desire, nor skill, to wish to tinker to keep the printer running, and Bambu Labs seems to as close to that as I have seen so far, apart from their locked firmware........


Good video, thanks.

author: @AntiVaganza
text:
@RickyImpey The following will sound harsh and it's likely I am venting my frustration with the tribe of reviewing content creators you belong to - but I think there are some truths in there a lot of you choose to ignore:

Sorry, you seem like a good, decent reviewer but I am getting tired of the "I did not get paid" cop out like that makes everything perfectly OK. No money changed hands, but you got two free printers (I assumed) ahead of an official launch and time to make a review which means we are now watching your content and helping you get paid by YT. 

I do know this is not free money and that you did put the work in, but the mechanism is real. Without being on the nice list of the companies you don't get early access and you don't get the clicks, right?
Also, one thing a lot of "independent" reviewers do is to not review products that they can't do a mostly positive review on - hence, skewing the overall picture the consumers get to see. 
On a related note, there's a reason why proper journalists aren't allowed to receive gifts of any kind or even a paid meal by an interviewee because we know staying fully independent is an illusion as soon as you do. Or at the very least, you open yourself up to people not trusting the reporting. 

I don't know where you fall on this spectrum, but to just state you don't take money doesn't mean you aren't making money from the affiliation. Also, I guess nice of you to give cudos to your contact at Elegoo who took care of you during her/his holidays. On the other hand, perhaps they wouldn't do that to a non-youtuber? Either way, I personally found it a tad worrying. They have a huge interest in making you happy ahead of their big launch, that's likely why they did it. While that person might be a nice person, you just gave the impression that this is a standup company that will pull out all the stops to help the customers. Would a good journalist have thanked a company CEO for "taking time out of their busy schedule" to talk to the publication about the great new product they are launching?

For years I have longed for one of you to take your reviews in a different direction - be the one that B U Y S the printers with patreon donations or your YT payment (many of them are getting so cheap it should be doable) and yes, your review will be a few weeks late, but you will be the one we will all actually trust 100%. 

I think the time is ripe for that...

author: @wide.wombat
text:
It is actually shocking (sic!) to see the voltage at the case. Discontinuity in the PE or not, the device MUST NOT have any live voltage at the case. I suspect, that in fashion similar to QIDI Q1 Pro, the heater is not controlled by double pole relay - the provided cable might have reversed L and N and does not bring L to the case, but N...  Very dangerous design. 

Secondly, I am worried that the RCD did not trip when you were shocked, started doing the voltage tests or finally when used the PE continuous cable. Yes, the currents weren't that high, but that's exactly what the RCD are designed for - to trip when there is any leakage, often to the annoyance of the users. Please, have those checked!

author: @JeffreyHawkins
text:
You have actually found a very big electrical issue. It sounds like Neutral and Ground are reversed or connected at some point in the printer. Under proper operation, voltage comes in on the Line/Hot wire. Work is done as the current flows through the electronics to the Neutral (NOT ground) wire. All other conductive parts are linked and connected to ground as a safety net, in case something hot inadvertently touches a conductive non-electronic part like the frame. Ground will never have voltage unless something extremely serious is wrong.

So, what you discovered was two safety issues... Something hot is in fact touching or connected to the frame when it shouldn't be. And your ground circuit was in a state of failure, preventing it from acting as the safety net it is intended to be.

If two printers in a row had this same issue, there has likely been a manufacturing run (where two wires were reversed. Or someone on the line is putting them together wrong. Please make sure this info gets to someone at Elegoo who will understand the problem... They likely will need to halt all shipments and recall immediately.

author: @mrfunkington
text: You do realize that the ground and neutral are tied together.

author: @wide.wombat
text: @mrfunkington It's better to stop talking when you have no training on the matter. There are multiple earthing arrangements - TN, TNS, TNC-S, TT. Yes, N and PE eventually come together - but definitely not on the consumer side of RCD.

author: @JeffreyHawkins
text: ‚Äã@mrfunkington If they were tied together in the way that you appear to be assuming, there would be zero need for both wires. They both terminate to the same bar in the electrical box (yes... they are tied together there), but this is not the same as being tied together in the appliance. In one case (what you are implying), a faulty ground line can kill someone. In the other, it serves as a safety feature as described.

author: @mitchellcrane9809
text: I would suggest further investigation on the voltage on the case. Grounding is a backup incase there is a fault somewhere. The fact there was a break in the ground in the cable does not explain voltage on the case. If it is only happening during bed heating there is a lack of isolation in the SCR, wiring from SCR to bed or bed itself. There should always be full isolation between case and mains voltage.

author: @JasonBurchell76
text:
Glad to see you‚Äôre releasing new stuff. I binged watched your library to catch up, started looking forward to your reviews and tutorials, then‚Ä¶.
Glad to see you‚Äôre still producing content. I haven‚Äôt watched the entire video, as I‚Äôm writing this comment. I hope by the end you have ran off a speed Benchy with the new Centauri Carbon. Another channel to which I subscribe did a review on Elegoo‚Äôs Carbon but didn‚Äôt squeeze out a Benchy. He explained as to why, and I get it. I‚Äôd just like the latest measure of a 3d printer measured with the benchmark we are all familiar with. 

Thanks for the video. I look forward to those to come.

author: @RickyImpey
text: Yes, loads more coming, I just don't tie myself down to a regular release schedule, I prefer to make content when there's something it think people want to see. Sometimes that can mean 10 videos in a month, sometimes none. I'm kind of coming away from the Benchy a bit as everything I've had sent to me over the past year can print them with no problem and speed runs can very much be down to how much you play with settings etc. It used to be that you could read a lot from a Benchy but not so much anymore. I'm on the lookout for a new version that's a bit harder to print and will tell us more. The CC is pretty much just as capable as all the klipper core XY printers that are available from the know brands, the only differences are the things I discuss in the video.

author: @DefNextYear
text: Fantastic walk through! The only item I would add is my printer arrived with two large black plastic clamps literally screwed onto the tower posts, one on each side. These must be removed or else it will make an awful sound during calibration and kick back an error saying "homing z axis failed". The printed directions don't mention anything about this.

author: @nickk6518
text:
Against my better judgement, I invested in this same 40W model which was delivered the first week of August (2025) and I think this is the first video so far that doesn't just show you how to put the thing together and then tell you how easy it all is. Like you, I had major trouble getting my 2017 MacBook Pro to recognise the machine. Despite the fact that it uses USB-C it seems that connecting to a MacBook which also has USB-C ports doesn't work if you use a USB-C to USB-C cable. As with other things the documentation it doesn't address this possibly Mac-specific issue.  Also, the documentation on the micro-SD card is rather Mac-unfriendly. In the folder '5. Software Operation Manual" the Lightburn User Manual refers to settings that may be different in the Mac version of the software and (unless I am mistaken) where it tells you to select the COM port to connect the device, on Macs the drop-down does not display, for example, COM3, so it can be a bit tricky to figure out the correct port to use. I'm actually thiking about re-writing that documentation to be Mac-specific so that other people don't get flustered when thigs don't seem to work.

One thing that I did notice is that it is actually possible to swap the two side panels over so that the fan and port are on the right side not the left. It does mean you need to flip the fan round, but that's easy, and it does also mean that the power cable is not long enough to reach the socket on the inside front-left of the unit. I am going to contact Creality and suggest that they include in the box an extensions cable but I bought some 24AWG silicone-sleeved wire which I am going to splice into the existing fan cable with some cable management on the inside back of the case and hope the fan still works!

The other thing you mentioned was the height of the unit off a level surface. I bought a 'bundle' offer from Creality from their eBay shop and it came with a large honeycomb bed, a Rotary Tool Pro and a set of four risers which you just screw in where the existing feet are. Alternatively, you could just use four baked bean cans, I guess!!

author: @patric001eede4
text:
Same type of behavior as with X-Plus/Max3 with their tool-board with a RP2040 and max-temp limit of 80C. Using the chamber-heater there pushed the chip well above it's operating-limit. Same for printing PLA/PETG where their "fix" was to print with a open enclosure. Then we got the issues with heat-creep in their hotend due to inadequate cooling.
Heck they updated the firmware reducing the max chamber temperature from what the product was specified to manage.

Kits where made available to fix some of the issues, but only the ones that noticed the issues during the first year of ownership would get anything.

I know one thing. No more qidi-products in our printfarm, at least until they prove they can be trusted.

author: @MMIC246
text:
I don‚Äôt have a Qidi X-Plus 4 yet, but I plan on getting one. Qidi is an excellent company with reliable printers. All 3D printers can be fire hazards, as stated in every manual: do not leave the printer unattended. I am confident Qidi will address any issues that arise. If a fire occurs, it‚Äôs important to remember that this risk is universal to all printers, not just Qidi's. It's unfortunate to wait for replacement parts, but Qidi‚Äôs commitment to fixing issues is commendable. In contrast, I‚Äôve struggled with Glowforge for two weeks to get a schematic for a known circuit board issue. Glowforge is a company to avoid. Qidi‚Äôs openness speaks volumes about their dedication to customers. Speaking to the Qidi CEO is possible; try reaching Creality's ANYONE with printer problems‚Äî

The real safety hazard in any printer is the hot end. By monitoring the printer as instructed, you‚Äôll catch issues before they escalate. Qidi printers are no riskier than other models. I have the original X-Plus, and it excels in printing various materials. Whenever I have questions, Qidi‚Äôs support is prompt and helpful. MANY companies sell 3D printers, but VERY FEW offer such great customer support. If anyone has a $700 xplus 4 they want to trade for a $7,000 Glowforge pro once its fixed, id do it in a second.  Qiditech 3d printers rock. Get at me about the Blowforge if anyone has one of these printers they are scared of. #Qidi3d QIDI TECH

author: @jefft490
text: The new board is installed on my Plus4, issue gone!   Continues to be a beast of a 3d printer, love this machine.  Prints flawless abs prints up to 305mm, it has seen hundreds of hrs of run time since receipt on 25 September. Just about all prints were high temp heated chamber with many hrs of engineering grade filaments run with ease in it.   Make sure you know on new board the wiring on right side changes from original, watch their whole video beginning to end before changing or putting in new board.  Use flashlight to find how left side of casing releases from inside, took about 2 minutes but found spot that allows it to release..... WIll add a second plus4 in future and just saw they doing BF sale til early Dec, the Q1 Pro which I also own has price that is very hard not to push buy button, tempting great sale price for Q1 Pro which has amassed hundreds of hours of non stop abs at my shop.  I will do huge shoutout to QIDI support they are fantastic and they go above and beyond.  I own three of their printers and the support rocks!  The heated chamber issue only on 115v systems does not effect UK.  New board and updated firmware takes care of any and all concerns.   They took care of issue and added one yr extended warranty, outstanding.  Glad did not have to ship back or wait long time for new printer.   QIDI has excellent support staff and come a long ways over the past few years.   Like other companies like Bambu, recalls or issues happen with pace they release these machines, like Bambu they learn and adapt and instantly resolved issues and all future production will see updates.  QIDI been known to adopt beta tester and user updates right into their manufacturing based on customer feedback, what's not to like?  They rock!

author: @orthodium
text: My plus 4 just majorly crapped its pants after only 3 weeks of use. To be fair the printing quality was good, but the issues started to creep up very quickly, when first the back cover of the print head got repeatedly violently torn off during the rapid front-right corner bump motion, then a bigger issue popped up whereby if the print job got paused for any reason, the resumption of the printing would start off at a shifted XY position ruining whatever has been printed before. Then the nozzle would start coming out of the pre-print purging/cleaning procedure with blobs of material stuck on it, ruining the ensuing print. The firmware update did not resolve the XY shift of print resumption, but instead just killed the machine entirely, with the table being forcibly jammed right against the ceiling limit and the print head would then lodge right into the print bed, at which point the machine was basically done. Qidi, while replying fairly quickly to their credit, tried to wiggle themselves out of acknowledging the entire host of issues by referring to this cluster**** as a singular "anomaly" and gratuitously providing me with some google link for my further education. Not until I firmly insisted on returning the unit (which luckily crapped out literally one day before their 30 day stated warranty was running out) only then reluctantly they promised to send me the shipping label next week which is yet to be seen. So the moral of the story is that you should only purchase this unit with some kind of extended warranty, unless you do enjoy having an $800 brick decorating your house.

author: @nansjes1
text: Qidi presents themselves as making professional printers, their website feels like they're competors with Bambu Lab, or even Ultimaker and thus you would expect a quality 3D printer. However, these issues show that Qidi may not have tested the printer's safety enough. Of course edge cases should be tested: different voltage levels, operating in too hot environment etc. I'd say thermal issues are the biggest safety concern for any 3D printer manufacturer, and even a cheap FLIR camera attached to a phone would've presented this problem with an obvious white dot that represents an out-of-spec temperature. Now,, the issue is remedied with people being asked if they want to work on mains voltage, as well as a firmware upgrade to limit power. The latter seems like a bandaid solution to me, because relays can fail and firmwares can get stuck. In my opinion: do better Qidi

author: @DaltoeMusic
text: Thanks for the thorough investigation!! I'm on 240v, so hopefully my heater board is safe. However, after 1.5 weeks of low-moderate use (with low-moderate speeds), some other issues have started appearing on my production unit. The machine has developed a mild, but noticeable scratching/grinding sound whenever the tool head moves along x-y rails. It is hard to tell if the noise is coming from the the belt rollers, rail/shaft bearings or stepper motors. It actually feels a bit rough or gritty when I manually slide and reposition the tool head. The original grease on the lead screws has already started turning from a white color to grey, which I hope isn't being caused by premature wear on the metal contact surfaces. I guess there is a chance that could be from printing black filament (if some strings or particles found their way onto the tracks). The final issue could be more cause for concern... I think it was @noizieworks that pointed out that some of the cables coming from under the heater in the build plate tend to rub on the side of the chamber. Today I noticed another small, insulated cable plugged into a connector on the back edge of the bed, and this cable is rubbing on the black plastic below the air filter. Within two weeks of operation I can see signs of frictional wear on the cables plastic insulation sleeve - which I think is concerning and, with everything else combined, I am starting to think this might be a recall or warranty replacement. I would like to know if these issues are confined to my machine, or whether there is a bigger QC problem underlying all of this.

Thanks for replying and your reply is fair given the context of the current thumbnail/title combination but at the time I commented, my comment was relevant and a fair assessment of driving viewers through click-bate "labeling" of the video.

author: @MichaelJHathaway
text: The problem is that the Qidi design didn't anticipate their printers being used with 120 volts, like that we use in the United States. It is not the coil that is the issue, but the large yellow box on the pcboard. Watts are equal to the volts multiplied the current. Therefor the problem is that 220volts X 1.82ampre = 400 watts, but 120volts X 3.33ampre = 400 watts. So at the lower USA voltage, the current increases and the original relay was not designed to handle the higher current. In my opinion, you should change it out regardless, but I think it will be ok if you just add a larger fan to the electronics chamber if you are at 220v. Changing the relay out to a heat sinkable Solid State Relay is safer, it has a cooling surface to dissipate heat and the switch is transistorized instead of a mechanical coil and arm. Do Not Use SSR's made in China! Taiwan, Japan, USA are good. The current firmware drops the output to the chamber heater down to 150 watts. After you have replaced your SSR, you will need to increase the wattage. I would keep the control setting close to 90C since the chamber heater housing is made out of ABS plastic.

author: @helixx_4D
text:
I think what added to this fervor was the fact that I filed a complaint with the U.S. Consumer Products Safety Commission last week. I copied this complaint to a Qidi rep in an email. 
I had been using this machine with the chamber heater for many hours while I slept & away from my print room for hours during the day! After opening the machine I found the inductor coils to be severely burnt & darkened. It really upset me!
That's when I got into the mix. 
Qidi is sending me the latest iteration of the board next week & Ill be reporting my own findings next week to the community. 
Disclaimer: 
If customers aren't confident working with Mains AC wiring, DO NOT ATTEMPT TO REPLACE THE BOARD! Seek out help from a licensed electrical engineering technician.

author: @zetapal
text: Are they still using glue only to secure the bottom bearing or did they fix that too ? Everybody do your research on this machine before purchase.

author: @chromamaster6147
text: Glue in a heated chamber was not a recipe for longevity.

author: @stew675
text:
This was a great summary of the issue, the current state of play of the fixes, while still separating the specific issue from the quality of the rest of the product.

I still think that it reflects somewhat poorly on Qidi that it has fallen to content creators like Ricky, Dan (ModBot), Nozieworks, and Grant (3DMusketeers) to communicate to the broader Qidi customers base and update them on the issue as opposed to Qidi taking the initiative and getting ahead of the problem and putting out an official statement to upgrade the firmware, and to avoid using the chamber heater if you live in a 110-120VAC region until a proper fix is finalised and made available to customers.

Grant tested yesterday on a live-stream what appears to be an alpha version of the final fix board, and found it to solve the issues of overheating components on the chamber heater power supply board for 110-120VAC regions.  The ball is firmly in Qidi's court to take affirmative action here and communicate to users as soon as possible about the situation and the path to a solution.

As far as I remember, Bambu Lab only did a recall after a lot of backlash.

At first they just offered a small plastic piece that you clip over the cable as a solution and claimed that it was the users' fault because they bent the cable. Then they tried to blame the shipping company and sell it as shipping damage. And finally, they offered a $120 voucher to anyone who replaced the heatbed on their own. They are not really any better than Qidi in that respect.

I just noticed how Bambu Lab first tried to pass the buck, then told influencers to tell their viewers to stop using the printer, and then took several days to issue a statement to the press. In the meantime, the US Consumer Product Safety Commission got involved.

Incidentally, what you did with the heatbed is no different from what is now being criticised. In some countrys it would be illegal to do so. Better don't tell your insurance company about this.

author: @802Garage
text:
Everything in this video is accurate. There is no issue on 230V, there have been zero fires thus far, the old board still gets too hot even on the new firmware, everyone in a 120V region should request a new board. Great job with the coverage.
I will say in addition the new version of the power supply has gotten to a few hands, including Grant's. He tested it as maintaining reasonable temperature. I should be able to test mine this weekend. Everyone who has looked at it says it is much more suited to task.
I am a huge fan of this printer, the quality it produces is awesome. I am also a believer that Qidi actually cares about customers, but rushed this launch and still needs experience dealing with this kind of problem. The Qidi owner community is great though.
I also think it would be better to make a public statement when a defect is known rather than just when a solution is finished, and I have told them so. I sincerely hope nobody has any larger issues and that Qidi will take everything they have learned from this launch to drastically improve the next.
Truly excellent coverage of this issue!

author: @dalemiller3639
text: Everything in this video is NOT accrete. He says to put the wires back in the way they came out and this is not true. The wires go in a different order on the new board.  Doing it how he states to do it could cause a serious problem. It needs to  be done according to the instruction sheet that comes with the board, NOT how he says to do it. This video should be taken down before he causes someone to burn their house down.

author: @802Garage
text: @dalemiller3639¬† He says "It appears" that replacement will just be R&R, but he also notes to pay close attention to wire order. Every replacement board comes with a card showing you the correct wire order. If you put the wires on the new board in the same order they are on the old board, nothing bad happens, it just doesn't function. I know because early users who received them did so. It does not even damage the board. You simply have to switch two wires. Please don't spread fear mongering misinformation.

author: @IanBradbury
text:
I had been considering purchasing, well, at the time it would be pre-ordering,  a Plus 4. ¬†Specifically I wanted the heated chamber as I print a fair amount of ASA and having my machines in a cold workshop I was sure the heated chamber would be very helpful.  I was ready to place the order when suddenly I hear about this issue.  Throwing the brakes on me placing an order.  

I'm in the UK and I don't care what they say about machines in 220-240v countries being safe - with the firmware update.  I need assurance that the machines are safe, now and in the future.  The only way they can achieve that for me is to replace the part with a proven safe component no matter where the machine is in the world.  After all, what happens if a future firmware update accidentally rolls back the safety change.  And, will future machines be built using the revised component?

I have a Bambu A1 and their recent recall was a great example in how to deal with this issue.  Clear communication.  Clear actions.  As far as I can tell everyone is happy.  I know I am with my A1.

I'm now left wondering if Qidi a reliable company?  And wondering why Qidi are not communicating more publicly and transparently.

author: @MrKhapp
text: The part is perfectly safe at 220-240v, as the amps being drawn is half of that when on 110-120v.  Qidi overlooked the amperage being drawn at 110-120v.

author: @rikidawson7510
text:
From the low quality picture of the reply board.  The new board is more than capable of carrying the higher current needed on a 100-120 volt.
The board is very easy to replace. Just UNPLUG the printer and you won't get shocked.  If you're unsure about doing the work, just take a picture of the wiring before you start.

author: @MrKhapp
text: Qidi have release a newer version the uses a round coil instead of the "tower" style, and I believe the wiring is different so instructions need to be followed as it's not wired the same as the old one.

author: @rikidawson7510
text: @MrKhapp really, they didn't use the same wiring layout.  But yes the lower type coil is better as it uses a much thicker gauge wire, which allows more current with less resistance (heat)

author: @802Garage
text: @rikidawson7510 Further than that, they are now using a zero switching optocoupler, a much higher rated solid state relay with a beefy heat sink, and have added other improvements to the board. Fingers crossed it is a good permanent fix.

author: @brandonberkmortel9558

I'm putting it in as it seems quite simple and not a big deal to do

If so, then halving the voltage will actually half the current as the resistance remains the same.  So, is the problem then because the board tries to compensate for this somehow?  I really would love someone explaining exactly why that part would be getting hotter on 110V than on 220V.  EEVBlog?

author: @JasonBurchell76
text:
Sorry, gotta put my 2 cents in‚Ä¶

While waiting for the new board to arrive, consider moving the current board with the issue to the exterior of the machine, or, if feasible, leave it in place but rig up some temporary mounting. Adding a heatsink with a fan to the choke (inductor) could help manage heat more effectively in the meantime.

I agree that manufacturers should take all necessary steps to identify and resolve these issues, working out multiple solutions and implementing a fix as soon as possible. However, at this level of 3D printing, users of advanced equipment like this should also be capable of safely troubleshooting and applying quick fixes, allowing continued use of the new machine without significant downtime.

That said, if we‚Äôre calling this a ‚Äúcommunity,‚Äù then let‚Äôs extend that spirit to support the vendors who bring us the latest tech. Working together to overcome issues like this can strengthen the whole ecosystem.

Thanks, and let‚Äôs keep pushing the hobby forward.

Best,
Jason

author: @andreas.grundler
text:
I think that's less of a problem. I'm not very skilled at electrical work, but based on the footage even I could do the replacement.

The more important question is what the legal side looks like. One point that has come up time and again when people have had to replace the heatbed on their Bambu Lab A1 is that in some countries the law requires an electrician to do the work or at least certify it.

The difference between the A1 and the X-Max 4 is that you could argue that the A1 is often bought by people who are not very tech-savvy, whereas the X-Max 4 is more likely to be bought by people who have at least some experience with 3D printing.

author: @YahWho-is1tt
text:
Hello Rick-I
and thanks for sharing this good stuff!  Just came across this new one and - although this isn't really the most appropriate (best practices sort of thing) place to post such a question, maybe somebody will take one look and offer up what might to them be OBVIOUS???  If it's not YOU - well, I'll certainly understand!  But I have DEFINITELY found your videos to be sane and informative in the past, so - here goes:
I did the klipper upgrade to my old ender 3 some time back, and although it is actually up and running, there is a substantial problem that I've tolerated until now. But it's HIGH TIME I got it resolved, as it came up again this morning!  You see, since I did the upgrade, based upon a new main board plus a Pi clone I am unable to print anything in stand-alone mode!  All the gcode files of things I have uploaded (in most cases printed from mainsail on my desktop PC) are shown in the "SDCARD" menu choice, but no amount of pressing the thumbwheel switch will allow me to select said file and actually print it!  Other things work - like setting temps on bed or hotend, but not the fundamental function of printing from the card!  Lame, indeed!  
So my little query here amounts to: where would you think the problem might lie: the firmware on the mainboard or the OS on the rPi board?  I'm at a loss to guess - so in such cases I usually flip a coin (pocket binary decision utility).  Maybe I should check for updates for both.  
Usually it's not a problem to just kick it off from the old PC, but when I want another copy of a previous print, it seems like a minor nuisance to have to use the sledge hammer when it should have been feasible with the stapler on the desk.
Still really liking Klipper, though - guessing you agree!
Thanks again - and keep it up!

author: @Sm1te79
text:
I find that you have to be careful with the quality of work that the various Github dev teams have done for the different manufacturers. Force-X has been great for the 5M, but Rinkhalls is left to be desired for Anycubic devices. Their documentation is lacking and there is no record of being able to set Bed PID Calibration, Extruder PID Calibration, or Shaper Calibration. Without those details, a lot of damage can be done if someone attempts to use their firmware package. I brought these up as legitimate questions in their Discord and was told to read documentation. Not good enough when a dev says "I don't have to tune it." Not everyone's environment is the same and this is just short-sidedness on their part.  

Sadly Anycubic just doesn't have the support that FlashForge does and I hope more reputable dev teams come forward to support Anycubic.

author: @Punchmememe

author: @KennethScharf
text: First layers are dependant on how clean the bed is, how well it is leveled, and slicer settings.  NONE of these have ANYTHING to do with the printer firmware.  If t he bed is well leveled MECHANICALLY then the effective parallelism between the print head and the bed matters, which the printer firmware DOES control.  SO, in most cases, the first level being put down well doesn't really work better on Klipper or Marlin, though it may be easier to configure the printer with Klipper to get a good first layer.  After that, the odds of a first layer failure are probably about the same for either.  At least that's been my experience.

author: @firstNamelastName-ho6lv
text: He was talking about how nice it is to monitor it through the camera, and firmware can definitely impact the first layer. I have an adventurer 3 that absolutely sucks at bed leveling. Either it needs extensive hardware changes or firmware changes to make it reliable.

author: @davewilliams8050
text: I have an Ender 3 V2 gathering dust along with a Creality Sonic Pad that has never been configured for use. I now have an K1 Max that I use for 3d printing of repair parts and fun stuff for my 3 year old granddaughter. In the past a Raspberry Pi 4B running Octo Print was used to send models and monitor Ender 3 V2 prints. I would like to reuse my Ender 3 V2 and learn how to use Klipper. I  notice you have migrated to using a Raspberry Pi instead of a Sonic Pad. Can you share your thoughts on what additional benefits the Raspberry PI has vs the Sonic Pad?

author: @seancosta5068
text: I would also be curious what the benefits are moving from a Sonic Pad to a Raspberry PI.

author: @davewilliams8050
text: After doing some research and looking at Sonic Pad's releases including GitHub repositories, I came to the conclusion that Creality's implementation of Klipper is not fully open source. This means that new Klipper features and add ins may not be installable on the Sonic Pad. This should not be true regarding Klipper installs on Raspberry Pi or laptop computers IMO. Sonic Pad firmware hasn't been updated for 9 months or so too. I conclude that using a Raspberry Pi with a touchpad will be my choice going forward as well.

author: @redraider1480
text: Hi David, I hope you may have found a solution by now, but I ran into the same issue recently. Soon I realized that my wlan0 was not connected to the wifi network. It is very likely possible that you might have installed network manager, which I did, along with the klipperscreen interface software and it is messing with your wlan0.  To address this, I manually accessed the terminal on the pi (ctrl+alt+F1) and added the ssid and password (Code - nmcli device; nmcli device wifi connect "your_SSID" password "your_password" ). Some instructions have been provided in the Klipperscreen website under network section of troubleshooting. Chatgpt also provided a step-by-step instructions on resolving the issue. You will need to use usb keyboard and maybe a hdmi connection to external monitor to do this. This has let me remotely access moonraker/mainsail from your computer to follow along the next steps from Ricky's video.
